newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-S.Korea plans 19 nuclear plants, official says.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-S.Korea plans 19 nuclear plants, official says.

text.p: South Korea plans to build 19 nuclear power plants as part of a long-term effort to keep pace with growing demand for power, an official of the Korea Electric Power Corp said on Monday.

The nuclear plants, which include two super-sized plants of 1,300 megawatts each, would lift the share of nuclear-generated power in Korea to 33.1 percent of total power-making capacity, Woo-Chang Cho, deputy manager of the power planning department of Korea Electric told an energy conference in Sydney.
Construction of the first of the larger-sized plants could begin as early as next year, Cho said.
In 1994, nuclear power held 26.5 percent of the market, Cho said. If all the nuclear plants are built, it would represent 26,329 megawats of power, Cho said.

To meet overall demand for electricity, Cho said a currrent development plan calls for a total of 122 power plants to be built. South Korea is looking at constructing 29 coal-fired plants, 40 liquified natural gas plants, 11 oil-fired plants and 23 hydro and other plants, Cho said.
At the same time, a total of 6,190 megawatss od capacity would be retired, Cho said.
Electricity consumption in South Korea has been increasing an average of 12 percent a year for the last 15 years, Cho said.
In the short-term, peak load will continue to increase, owing to a rapid rise in the use of cooling appliances, he said.
Capital investments of between US$3 billion and $4 billion a year is required to meet the new demand, Cho said.
The plan calls for a further 38 plant sites, although only 22 sites have been secured so far, he said.
Obtaining sites is becoming more difficult because of opposition from local communities, Cho said.
Electric power demand has a tendency to be concentrated high-density populated areas, while power plants are located in remote places, he said.
"This causes difficulties in maintaing supply stability and high transmission loss," Cho said.
